int

lows, highs

the lower and upper bound of integration domain assumed to be the same for each dimension

the True solution to int integrand(x) dx

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.bayes_problems.BayesProblem(D: int, d: Distribution, lows, highs)[source]¶

Bases: Problem

base class for integration problems, with a prior density p and a likelihood d

D¶

dimension of the problem

Type:

int

d¶

the likelihood function in integral

Type:

Distribution

lows, highs

the lower and upper bound of integration domain must have length D

Type:

float or list or np.array

p¶

the density function in integral

Type:

Distribution, optional

answer¶

the True solution to int p.pdf(x) * d.pdf(x) dx integrated over [lows, highs]

Type:

float

integrand(X)[source]¶
rvs(n)[source]¶

Generate random samples from the likelihood distribution

Argument¶

nint

number of samples

returns:

samples from the distribution

rtype:

np.ndarray of shape (n, self.D)

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.bayes_problems.Camel(D)[source]¶

Bases: BayesProblem

d¶
Likelihood: mixture of Two Gaussians

centred at 1/3 and 2/3 along unit diagonal. cov = 1/200.

Type:

Distribution

p¶

Prior: U([-0.5, 1.5]^D)

Type:

Distribution

D¶

dimension of the problem

Type:

int

lows, highs

the lower and upper bound of integration domain, from -0.5 to 1.5 in each dimension

Type:

numpy.ndarray

answer¶

1 / (2.0**self.D)

Type:

float

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.bayes_problems.Gaussian(D, mu=None, Sigma=None, lows=None, highs=None)[source]¶

Bases: BayesProblem

Integration of general Gaussian pdf on rectangular bounds

Parameters:

  • D (int) – Dimension of the problem

  • d (Distribution) –

    Multivariate Gaussian with

    mean mu and covariance Sigma

  • mu (numpy.ndarray) – Mean vector

  • Sigma (numpy.ndarray) – Covariance matrix

  • lows (numpy.ndarray) – Bounds of the integration domain

  • highs (numpy.ndarray) – Bounds of the integration domain

  • answer (float) – The true solution

A challenging problem with more modes, more spread out, than those in Camel.

2,4,6,8 units along diagonal. cov = 1/200.

lows, highs

treeQuadrature.example_problems.complex_problems module¶

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.complex_problems.Oscillatory(D: int, u: int = 0, a: ndarray | None = None)[source]¶

Bases: Problem

A problem class representing an oscillatory integrand function for numerical integration or other mathematical evaluations.

The oscillatory function depends on a frequency vector a and a phase shift parameter u. The integration bounds are [0, 1] in each dimension.

D¶

The dimensionality of the problem.

Type:

int

a¶

The frequency vector of the oscillatory function.

Type:

numpy.ndarray

u¶

The phase shift parameter of the oscillatory function.

Type:

float

answer¶

The analytic solution to the integral of the function over the entire domain.

Type:

float

compute_answer(a, u)[source]¶
integrand(X) → ndarray[source]¶

Oscillatory integrand function.

Mathematically, the integrand function is defined as:

\[f(x) = \cos\left(2\pi u + \sum_{i=1}^D a_i x_i\]

ight)

where: - ( x = (x_1, x_2, dots, x_D) ) is the input vector. - ( u ) is a scalar that shifts the phase of the cosine function. - ( a = (a_1, a_2, dots, a_D) ) is a vector that controls the frequency of

oscillation along each dimension.

  • ( D ) is the dimension of the input space.

The function exhibits oscillatory behavior as ( x ) varies, with the frequency of oscillation determined by the values in the vector ( a ).

Xnumpy.ndarray

Each row is an input vector.

numpy.ndarray of shape (N, 1)

the function value evaluated at X

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.complex_problems.Ripple(D, a=3)[source]¶

Bases: Problem

A problem class representing a ripple-like integrand function for numerical integration or other mathematical evaluations.

The ripple function has an oscillatory behavior controlled by the parameter a and is defined over a D-dimensional space with bounds from -10 to 10 in each dimension.

D¶

The dimensionality of the problem.

Type:

int

a¶

A parameter controlling the frequency of the ripple in the integrand function. Default is 3.

Type:

float, optional

answer¶

The analytic solution to the integral of the function over the entire domain.

Type:

float

integrand(X) → ndarray[source]¶

Ripple integrand function.

Mathematically, the integrand function is defined as:

\[f(x) = \exp\left(-\]

rac{|x|^2}{2} ight) cdot cos^2left(a |x|^2 ight)

where: - ( x = (x_1, x_2, dots, x_D) ) is the input vector. - ( |x| ) is the Euclidean norm of the vector ( x ),

given by ( |x| = sqrt{sum_{i=1}^D x_i^2} ).

  • ( a ) is a scalar that controls the frequency of the ripples.

The function exhibits a combination of exponential decay and oscillatory ripple patterns as ( |x| ) varies.

Xnumpy.ndarray

Each row is an input vector.

numpy.ndarray of shape (N, 1)

the function value evaluated at X

treeQuadrature.example_problems.distributions module¶

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.distributions.Camel(D, weights=None)[source]¶

Bases: MixtureDistribution

Specific multimodal distribution used as a test in the literature.

A pair of D-dimensional gaussian distributions,

with shared covariance sigma=1/200 I, and means placed at 1/3 and 2/3 along the unit hypercube diagonal.

Default weights are equal

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.distributions.Distribution(D)[source]¶

Bases: ABC

An abstract framework for distributions for defining BayesProblem.

abstract pdf(X, *args, **kwargs) → ndarray[source]¶

Calculate the probability density function (pdf) at given point x.

Parameters:

  • *args – Additional arguments and keyword arguments for the pdf computation.

  • **kwargs –

    Additional arguments and keyword arguments for the pdf computation.

Returns: numpy.ndarray

The probability densities at x_i (rows of X)

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.distributions.QuadCamel(D, weights=None)[source]¶

Bases: MixtureDistribution

Complementary test to the camel, more humps, more spaced out.

4 D-dimensiona gaussian distributions,

with shared covariance 1/200 I, and means placed at 1,3,5,7 along the unit hypercube.

Default weights are equal

treeQuadrature.example_problems.simple_problems module¶

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.simple_problems.C0(D: int, u: ndarray | None = None, a: ndarray | None = None)[source]¶

Bases: Problem

integrand(X) → ndarray[source]¶

C0 integrand function.

\[\]

f(X) = expleft(-sum_{i=1}^{D} a_i cdot |x_i - u_i|

ight)

where:

  • (X = (x_1, x_2, dots, x_D)) is the input vector,

  • (a = (a_1, a_2, dots, a_D)) is a vector of coefficients,

  • (u = (u_1, u_2, dots, u_D)) is the vector of center points.

The function represents an exponential decay based on the sum of weighted absolute differences between each component of the input vector and the corresponding component of the center vector.

Xnumpy.ndarray

Each row is an input vector.

numpy.ndarray of shape (N, 1)

the function value evaluated at X

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.simple_problems.CornerPeak(D: int, a: ndarray | None = None)[source]¶

Bases: Problem

compute_answer(a0, a)[source]¶
integrand(X) → ndarray[source]¶

Corner Peak integrand function.

\[\]

f(x) = left(1 + sum_{i=1}^{D} a_i cdot x_i

ight)^{-(D+1)}

where: - \(x\) is a vector of input values, - \(a\) is a coefficient vector, - \(D\) is the dimensionality of the input space.

Xnumpy.ndarray

Each row is an input vector of shape (N, D), where N is the number of samples, and D is the dimensionality.

numpy.ndarray of shape (N, 1)

the function value evaluated at X

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.simple_problems.Discontinuous(D, a=None)[source]¶

Bases: Problem

A problem with a discontinuous integrand function.

The integrand is designed to be discontinuous at specified points u1 and u2. The function value drops to zero beyond these thresholds, creating a discontinuity in the domain.

D¶

Dimensionality of the problem.

Type:

int

a¶

one dimensional array, Coefficient vector for the exponential function.

Type:

np.ndarray

u1¶

Threshold for discontinuity in the first dimension.

Type:

float

u2¶

Threshold for discontinuity in the second dimension (if D > 1).

Type:

float

answer¶

The analytical solution of the integral for comparison.

Type:

float

handle_input(xs) → ndarray[source]¶

Check the shape of xs and change xs to the correct shape (N, D)

Parameter¶

xsnumpy.ndarray

the array to be handled

Return numpy.ndarray

the handled array

integrand(X) → ndarray[source]¶

Discontinuous integrand function.

The Discontinuous integrand function is defined as:

\[f(X) = egin{cases} \exp\left(\sum_{i=1}^{D} a_i \cdot x_i\]
ight) & ext{if } X ext{ lies in the specified region},

0 & ext{otherwise} end{cases}

where:

  • (X = (x_1, x_2, dots, x_D)) is the input vector,

  • (a = (a_1, a_2, dots, a_D)) is a vector of coefficients,

  • (u_1, u_2) are predefined thresholds.

Xnumpy.ndarray

Each row is an input vector.

numpy.ndarray of shape (N, 1)

the function value evaluated at X

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.simple_problems.ExponentialProduct(D)[source]¶

exact_integral(mins, maxs)[source]¶

Calculate the exact integral from mins to maxs for the product of exponentials.

Parameters:

  • maxs (numpy.ndarray) – Upper bounds of the integration.

Returns:

The value of the integral.

numpy.ndarray

class treeQuadrature.example_problems.simple_problems.ProductPeak(D: int, u: ndarray | None = None, a: ndarray | None = None)[source]¶

Bases: Problem

integrand(X) → ndarray[source]¶

Product Peak integrand function.

Mathematically, the integrand function is defined as:

\[f(x) =\]

rac{1}{prod_{i=1}^D left(a_i^{-2} + (x_i - u_i)^2 ight)}

where: - ( x = (x_1, x_2, dots, x_D) ) is the input vector. - ( u = (u_1, u_2, dots, u_D) ) is a vector representing the peak location. - ( a = (a_1, a_2, dots, a_D) ) is a vector controlling the

sharpness of the peak along each dimension.

  • ( D ) is the dimension of the input space.

Xnumpy.ndarray

Each row is an input vector.

numpy.ndarray of shape (N, 1)

the function value evaluated at X
